case_title: Mirza Mehboob (since deceased) through his legal heir Ahmed Ali Rauf Mirza vs Mst. Najma Begum & others
reference_no_or_id: Constitution Petition No. S â€“ 276 of 2024
appellant: Mirza Mehboob (since deceased) through his legal heir Ahmed Ali Rauf Mirza

accussed_details.name: Ahmed Ali Rauf Mirza
allegation: Refusal to vacate tenement despite notice

complaint_summary: Respondent filed Rent Case No.364/2021 under Section 14 of the Sindh Rented Premises Ordinance, 1979, seeking eviction of the tenant due to default in rent payment and personal bona fide need.
investigation_summary: Evidence was recorded by the Rent Controller, including affidavits and cross-examinations. Notice of eviction was sent to the tenant, who refused to comply.
judgment_summary: The Sindh High Court dismissed the petition, upholding the concurrent findings of the lower courts. The court ruled that the Respondent, being a widow, met the criteria under Section 14 of the Ordinance and required the premises for personal use.
punishment: Petition dismissed; tenant ordered to vacate premises.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition dismissed with no order as to cost.
legal_arguments: Petitioner argued that Section 14 does not cover default grounds and that Respondent had other tenements.
Respondent argued personal need as a widow and willful default by Petitioner.
assets: Shop No.5 constructed on Plot No.BS-15, Block-14, F.B. Area, Karachi

witness_statement.Son of Respondent No.1: Testified that Respondent No.1 required the premises for personal use and that notice of eviction was duly sent to the tenant.

key_issues: Applicability of Section 14 for eviction based on personal need
Distinction between Sections 14 and 15 of the Ordinance

legal_terms.Willful Default: Intentional failure to comply with rent payment obligations.

words_and_phrases.Personal Bona Fide Need: Requirement of premises for genuine personal use.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the eviction of a tenant under Section 14 of the Sindh Rented Premises Ordinance, 1979. The Respondent, a widow, sought possession of the premises for personal use. The courts upheld her claim, dismissing the Petitioner's arguments regarding default and possession of other tenements.
